column1: The landscape of Vulcan was changed to include a yellowish sky and new landscape featuring massive statues. Wes Craven and screenwriter Bruce Joel Rubin's original vision for the film was a PG-rated supernatural science fiction thriller
column2: with the primary focus being on the macabre love story between Paul and Samantha
column3: as well as a secondary focus on the adults around them and how they are truly monsters inside themselves. Craven filmed this version of the film and Warner Bros. decided to screen it to a test audience mostly consisting of Craven's fans. The response from fans was negative
column4: criticizing the lack of violence and gore seen in Craven's previous films. The studio eventually discovered Craven's popularity as a horror film director. The president of Warner Bros. at the time
column5: Mark Canton
column6: demanded Rubin write six additional gore scenes into his script
column7: each bloodier than the last. Rubin worked very hard with Craven to create a very deep and heartfelt movie out of it. Unfortunately
column9: re-shoots and post production re-editing of the movie heavily changed the original story. Craven and Rubin expressed strong anger at the studio and thus disowned the film.: 1

column1: Sir Carol Reed restricted Bobby Henrey's access to the cake trolley during tea breaks on-set so he wouldn't gain weight. A scene with Bobby running up the stairs was left half-completed at the end of the week's shooting on a Friday evening. Over the weekend
column2: Madeleine decided the boy needed a haircut
column3: and when he returned to the set on Monday
column4: it was impossible to match the remaining shots they needed to the ones taken a few days before. The Make-up Department tried attaching hair pieces to him
column5: but it didn't look right. Reed was furious and had no choice but to rearrange the shooting schedule to complete the stair scene after Bobby's hair grew out. "It's the most expensive haircut in the world!" Reed groused. "Thousands of pounds! That's what it will cost!" The incident was the only delay in an otherwise smooth shoot
column6: which ended up completing on schedule.: 1

column1: 's Cut runs 14 minutes longer (119 minutes). Among the changes:

The opening scene with Laurie walking and Loomis being placed into the ambulance is longer.The hospital dream scene has an extra sequence of Laurie attempting to cross over a pile of bodies.An on screen title that said "One Year Later" in the Theatrical Cut now says "Two Years Later."During the breakfast scene
column2: Laurie and Annie now argue about going to the psychiatrist.More dialogue with Laurie and the psychiatrist. Laurie looks at a framed inkblot on a wall and says that it looks like a white horse.Loomis' press conference is expanded. Loomis discusses Michael's Oedipal complex
column3: as well as the idea that Michael perhaps saw Loomis as a father figure.Added sequence where Laurie runs a bath and begins to freak out.Laurie stopping to play with a pig on her way to work is removed. She instead goes to the psychiatrist and tells her about playing with the pig (we see a few seconds of it
column4: now in flashback)
column5: and how it triggered a nervous breakdown of sorts. When the shrink denies her more pills
column6: Laurie freaks out and swears.The scene where Annie finds Laurie drinking a beer in her room has been expanded: They have another fight.A non-masked Michael (along with Young Michael and his mother) angrily looks at a billboard that advertises Loomis' book.When Laurie and Maya come home from the party
column7: there is a short added sequence of them making tea in the kitchen prior to going upstairs. There's also an added shot of Michael apparently walking out of the house.Brackett's reaction to finding Annie's body is longer
column8: containing video flashbacks of real-life actress Danielle Harris as a child.The ending is significantly different: After Loomis enters the cabin
column9: Michael throws him through a wall
column10: and the two of them wind up outside. Michael then removes his mask
column12: and stabs Loomis. The cops then open fire and kill Michael. Laurie then comes out
column15: implying that she may stab him. The cops then open fire on her and seemingly kill her. We then fade to the same hospital footage seen at the end of the theatrical cut as a cover of "Love Hurts" plays on the soundtrack.: 1

column1: Juan José Campanella was not happy with the English translation of the title. The original title was intentionally ambiguous

column1: F. Gary Gray decided to use Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steakhouse as the restaurant that caters Clyde's lunch after dining there several times during filming. The restaurant was also the location of the film's after-party following its screening at the Philadelphia Film Festival.: 1

Kevin Greutert mentioned in the commentary track that the twitching and shivering Amanda (Shawnee Smith) does in her scenes with Cecil (Billy Otis) was real due to low temperatures and rain in Toronto at the time of filming. Shawnee couldn't stop shivering because she was cold and they were shooting outdoors.: 1
Edward James Olmos stated in the DVD commentary that he made several homages to The Boy with Green Hair (1948)
column2: which starred a then twelve year old Dean Stockwell. Stockwell portrayed Peter Fry
column3: a war orphan whose hair inexplicably turned green when he discovered that his parents had been killed during the Second World War. One example was when Cavil asked the boy John "Are you a war orphan?". This question was asked of Peter Fry several times in The Boy with Green Hair (1948).Olmos also used a still shot picture of Peter Fry from the movie when casting for the character of John the Boy
column4: because he wanted the actor to bear a strong resemblance to how Stockwell looked in his adolescence. Alex Ferris resemblance to Stockwell's picture helped get him cast. At one point
column5: Olmos wanted John the Boy's hair color to be green like Peter Fry's character
column6: but was ultimately overruled by the producers.: 1
